data.title: Batch flattened sprite content
QuadBatch not visible
data.body: I used a QuadBatch made of parts of a single texture 1024x1024. In Google Chrome flash player with debug and non-debug versions (13,0,0,182 and 13.0.0.214) this QuadBatch is invisible in 9/10. In Firefox it looks fine (same 13,0,0,182 player).

data.title: [API Request] Add findAncestor() method to DisplayObject
Converting Button fields to protected instead of private?
data.body: We subclass Button to do a few of our own funky logic to it and every time we update to the latest version we need to switch all of the fields, and onTouch to protected instead of their default private.  Just wondering if there is any reason to have the class completely closed with privates, instead of subclass-able with protecteds instead and if not you'd accept a pull request with them being set to protected?

data.title: optimize getNames() by pre-sorting the names and use loop with vector instead of dictionary
data.body:
Hi, 

We have a performance issue with loading textures on our mobile app so we try to optimize some stuff. In this patch, we avoid to loop within the Dictionary and sort in getNames.

Thanks,

data.title: Allow cheap ColorMatrix effects by specialized shader code
data.body: Add the option to the QuadBatch class to use a matrix to perform color matrix operations at rendering with just one additional AGAL instruction.

data.title: processTouches function bug
After upgrading to 1.5 AssetManager throws exception
Blank Bitmap TextFields Cause null pointer error on starling CONTEXT3D_CREATE event
Visual Desync Between Display List and Stage3D
data.body:
As per recommendation in this thread (http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/stage3d-visual-lag-on-osx) I'm opening this issue here.

I'm exporting a program for mac and windows which, on mac, renders every stage3D object exactly one frame later than it should.

I'm able to fix this on mac by forcing my Starling object to call nextFrame(), however, doing so causes the exact same kind of lag to occur on windows instead. This single line that fixes the issue on one computer breaks it on the other. At this point I'm not sure if the problem lays in mac/windows or some other difference between the computers I've tested on.

data.title: Using composition instead of inheritance for MovieClip
data.body:
Hi,

I would suggest to use composition for MovieClip instead of directly extending Image so we can re-use the logic for advancing, looping, events.. while using another rendering method than just switching texture (for example, my use case, in the GAF library or Spline etc..).

A way could be to create an IAnimatable AnimationManager who knows about the number of frames, current frame etc.. and use one of theses in the MovieClip.
That way, we could create another Animated display object easily without rewriting a bunch of code.

data.title: ArgumentError outdated or implementation wrong?
juggler.removeDelayedCall
data.body:
added `juggler.removeDelayedCall(call)` to be able to remove a previously added `DelayedCall` with `juggler.delayedCall()` method or a manually added `DelayedCall` to the juggler. 
I just cloned the `juggler.removeTweens()` function and added a getter to the actual call in the `DelayedCall`

data.title: Juggler.delayedCall returns supertype.
data.body:
public function delayCall(call:Function, delay:Number, ...args):IAnimatable

should return DelayedCall as in previous versions.

data.title: Added a way to upload an array of bitmaps for textures with custom mipmap levels
data.body:
This patch allows a user to upload custom mipmaps to be used for a texture. Custom mipmaps are useful when creating textures that render different content depending on the resolution it is being drawn. In my own case, I'm using textures with custom mipmaps to simulate lines with a uniform thickness: whatever the texture of my quad, the lines drawn on it have the same thickness. Such a solution is best used when combined with trilinear filtering, since it interpolates the texture between different mimap levels.

This patch doesn't break compatibility with the current version of Starling. It adds two new methods:

`Texture.fromBitmapDatas(datas:Array of BitmapData)`
and
`<ConcreteTexture>.uploadBitmapDatas(datas:Array of BitmapData, optimizeForRenderToTexture:Boolean=false, scale:Number=1, format:String="bgra", repeat:Boolean=false)`

It also changes `<ConcreteTexture>.uploadBitmapData()` to call `<ConcreteTexture>.uploadBitmapDatas()` to avoid duplicating code.

In a nutshell, the new `uploadBitmapDatas()` works the same way as the old `uploadBitmapData()`. The difference is that it uses the first BitmapData instance in the array as the main texture, and subsequent instances as mipmap levels for it. It would work like this:

`var texture:Texture = Texture.fromBitmapDatas([bitmap256x256, bitmap128x128, bitmap64x64, ...]);`

It continues using bitmaps (it assumes each subsequent bitmap is half the resolution of the previous) until there's no more bitmapdatas available. When this happens, it falls back to resizing the last image and using it as the next mipmap level (again, similar to what the original `uploadBitmapData()` does).

I'm open to suggestions of a different interface. I have been using this patch on a current project and it plays well with normal Starling content.

Other details:
- This patch does not make any attempt to hook into the asset manager and allow upload of bitmaps for separate mipmap levels. I don't use the AssetManager that much and I don't think I'd come up with the ideal interface for it.

data.title: juggler.delayCall cannot be reset properly
data.body: Hi, we cannot use **juggler.delayCall()** and keep the **DelayedCall** created and use **reset()** on it. At the end of the call it will be moved to the pool even if we still want to use it. Can't we add an argument _usePool_ in the function call or something like that ?

data.title: Mouse-based Touches have unique IDs
Proper IDs for mouse-based TouchEvents?
data.body:
Is it possible to give proper, non-repeating IDs to TouchEvents that come from the mouse, rather than assigning ID 0 to all mouse touch events?

I frequently run into variations on the following scenario:
- input-listener-1 processes a mouseDown
- input-listener-2 processes the same mouseDown
- input-listener-1 processes the following mouseUp, and uses my input manager to "consume" the touch event, so that no other listeners receive it
- input-listener-2 receives a future, unrelated mouseUp and incorrectly assumes it's the same TouchEvent it was dealing with before because the ID is always 0

Obviously this situation could be solved by ensuring that all input-listeners are informed whenever an event is consumed by another listener - but this is (possibly) expensive, and is not necessary when dealing with "real" TouchEvents on a touchscreen device, where each new touch gets its own ID.

I'd love to not have to do extra book-keeping in the desktop version of my game.

I'd happily put together a pull request for this change if you don't have objections, Daniel.

data.title: mRepeat setter does not change value in TextureOptions.as
TextField onRestore with device fonts
data.body:
The TextField onRestore method might need a try/catch block when used with device fonts, as Jeff comments on this thread:

http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/error-3694-from-textfieldtextbounds

data.title: Added static Starling.all property to get all Starling instances
data.body:
Similar to `Starling.current`, but it gets all Starling instances. An instance is added in its constructor and removed when its `dispose()` function is called.
## Use Cases

1) I have a reference to a `starling.display.Stage`. It would be nice if I could somehow get the `starling.core.Starling` instance that owns it. For instance, I might want to know the `nativeStage` that is associated with this Starling stage so that I can position something properly above Starling in an AIR `NativeWindow`. Looping through the vector returned by the static `Starling.all` property would allow me to find the right Starling instance pretty easily.

2) An AIR `NativeWindow` has a `stage` property, which makes it easy to access the native display list of the active window with `NativeApplication.activeWindow.stage`. However, there's no way to get a Starling stage for an arbitrary `NativeWindow`. Similar to the previous use case, I can loop through the static `Starling.all` property and check if `NativeApplication.activeWindow.stage` matches a Starling instance's `nativeStage` property.

data.body:

I got a redirect image to _load_ but Starling thinks it's a ByteArray, which is problematic since I can't find a way to convert it to a Texture.

data.title: drawToBitmapData using a scale
Error #3605 after the context restore with the Starling when using ATF texture on Android devices
data.body:
Created very simple example that can easily replicate this issue :
https://github.com/SlavomirDurej/starlinglostcontexbug/tree/master

All I'm doing is loading a spritesheet in ATF format, and adding an image from it on the screen :

``` as3
private function displayLoadedObj() : void
{
    var texture : Texture = assetManager.getTexture("Ring");
    var img : Image = new Image(texture);
    img.x = 1;
    img.y = 1;
    this.addChild(img);
}
```

(https://github.com/SlavomirDurej/starlinglostcontexbug/blob/master/src/com/durej/lostcontextbug/Main.as)

So shortly after starting the app, an image of a ring will appear on the screen. But when you trigger a context loss situation - in this case rotating device from portrait to landscape orientation I get the following error :

``` as3
Exception fault: Error: Error #3605: Sampler 0 binds an invalid texture.
    at flash.display3D::Context3D/drawTriangles()
    at starling.display::QuadBatch/renderCustom()[C:\_ftd_workspace_2013\lostcontextbug\src\starling\display\QuadBatch.as:239]
    at starling.core::RenderSupport/finishQuadBatch()[C:\_ftd_workspace_2013\lostcontextbug\src\starling\core\RenderSupport.as:362]
    at starling.core::Starling/render()[C:\_ftd_workspace_2013\lostcontextbug\src\starling\core\Starling.as:413]
    at starling.core::Starling/nextFrame()[C:\_ftd_workspace_2013\lostcontextbug\src\starling\core\Starling.as:370]
    at starling.core::Starling/onEnterFrame()[C:\_ftd_workspace_2013\lostcontextbug\src\starling\core\Starling.as:568]
```

The texture is in ETC format, with jpg compression applied (png2atf.exe argument -r)
mipmaps are set to -n 0.0..

I tried this on various Android devices from older (Kindle, Nook, to HTC Desire HD, Nexus 5) and on each device I could trigger above error..
Compiling for -swf-version=21

Using 4.6 Flex SDK, tried AIR SDK 3.9 and 4.0 also with ASC 2, makes no difference..

data.title: ATF textures problem with RenderTexture
data.body:
ATF textures works wrong where png textures are ok. Easiest way to repeat is Demo project compilation with atf atlas instead of png atlas: https://www.dropbox.com/s/fs695bkkgaij9d7/Demo.swf

I used these convertion parameters: png2atf.exe -c d -r -n 0,0 -i atlas.png -o atlas.atf (same result with other parameters)

RenderTexture scene looks broken. Also, you can see artifacts with brightness filter.

Only pixels with alpha<1 is causing the problem. Only with RenderTexture.draw() and FragmentFilter. No problem with atf textures as DisplayObject.

I found this problem in all Starling versions with atf support.

I think something wrong with PMA calculation, but I'm not sure.
